editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

keywords.term: Elizabeth, -- I, -- Queen of England, -- 1533-1603 -- Drama.

div.p: The second part of, if you know not me, you know nobody .
With the building of the royal exchange:
And the famous victory of Queen Elizabeth, in the year 1588.
At London, printed for Nathaniel butter. 1606.

div.head: The second part of if you know not me, you know nobody : with the building of the exchange.

sp.stage: Enter one of Gresham's factors and a Barbary merchant.

sp.speaker: Factor.
sp.l: My master sir, requests your company,
About confirming certain covenants
Touching your last night's conference.

sp.speaker: Marchant.
sp.l: The sugars.
Believe me, to his credit be it spoke,
He is a man of heedful providence,
And one that by innative courtesy
Wins love from strangers, be it without offence,
How are his present fortunes reckoned?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Neither to flatter nor detract from him,
He is a merchant of good estimate,
Care how to get, and forecast to increase,
(If so they be accounted) be his faults.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: They are especial virtues, being clear
From avarice and base extortion.
But here he comes: good day, to m. Gresham,
You keep your word.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Else should I ill deserve
The title that I wear, a merchant's tongue
Should not strike false.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: What think you of my proffer,
Touching the sugar?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I be thought myself
Both of the gain and losses incident,
And this I take't was the whole circumstance:
It was my motion and I think your promise,
To get me a seald patent from your King
For all your Barbary sugar at a price,
During the King's life; and for his princely love,
I am to send him threescore thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Was so conditioned, and to that effect
His highness' promise is already past,
And if you dare give credit to my trust,
Send but your private letters to your factor,
That deals for your affairs in Barbary,
His majesty shall either seal your patent,
Or I'll return the money to your factor.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: As much as I desire; pray sir draw near
And taste a cup of wine, whilst I consider
And thoroughly scan such accidental doubts,
As may concern a matter of such moment.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: At your best leisure.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.l: I'll resolve you straight.
Bethink thee Gresham, threescore thousand pounds
A good round sum: let not the hope of gain
Draw thee to loss. I am to have a patent
For all the Barbary sugars at a rate,
The gain clears half in half, but then the hazard:
My term continues during the King's life,
The King may die before my first return,
Then where's my cash? why, so the King may live
These 40. years, then where is Gresham's gain:
It stands in this as in all ventures else
Doubtful, no more, I'll through whate'er it cost.
So much clear gain, or so much coin clear lost.
Within there ho.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: At hand sir, did you call?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: How thrives our cash? what is it well increased?
I speak like one that must be forced to borrow.

sp.speaker: 1. factor
sp.l: Your worship's merry.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Merry, tell me knave,
Dost not thou think that three score thousand pounds,
Would make an honest merchant try his friends?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Yes, by my faith sir, but you have a friend
Would not see you stand out for twice the sum.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Praise God for all, but what's the common rumor
Touching my bargain with the King of Barbary?

sp.speaker: 1. factor
sp.l: 'Tis held your credit, and your country's honour,
That being but a merchant of the city,
And taken in a manner unprovided,
You should upon a mere presumption
And naked promise, part with so much cash,
Which the best merchants both in Spain and France,
Denied to venture on.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Good: but withal,
What do they think in general of the bargain?

sp.speaker: 1. factor
sp.l: That if the King confirm and seal your patent,
London will yield you partners enough.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I think no less: go fit you for the sea,
I mean to send you into Barbary:
You unto Venice, you to Portingale,
Provide you presently: where much is spent,
Some must be got, thrift should be provident:
Come hither cousin, all the rest depart.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I had as good depart too, for he'll ring a peal in mine
'Twill sound worse than a passing bell. (Care,

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I have ta'en note of your bad husbandry,
Careless respect, and prodigal expense,
And out of my experience counsel you.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: And I hope good uncle, you think, I am as ready to take good counsel, as you to give it, and I doubt not, but to clear, myself of all objections that foul-mouthed envy shall intimate against me.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: How can you satisfy the great complaint
Preferred against you by old mistress blunt.
A woman of approved honesty.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: That's true, her honesty hath been proved ofter than once or twice: but do you know her uncle? are you inward with her course of life, she's a common midwife for trade-fallen virginity, there are more maidenheads charged and discharged in her house in a year, than pieces at the artillery yard.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: She bring sin further proof, that you miscalled her.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I never called her out of name, by this hand uncle, to my remembrance:

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: No: she says you called her bawd.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: True; and I have known her answer to't a thousand times; tut uncle 'tis her name, and I know who gave it her too, by the same token her godfather gave her a bowed angel standing at the do re which she hath kept time out a mind.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Antonio reports you love his wife.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Love, why alas, uncle, I hold it parcel of my duty to love my neighbours, and should I hate his wife, no man would hold me a fit member for a common wealth.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: He hates you fort.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Why, alas uncle, that's not my fault, I'll love him ne'ertheless, you know we are commanded to love our enemies, and though he would see me hanged, yet will I love his wife.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: He told me, you bestowed a gown of a strumpet.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Why, alas uncle, the poor whore went naked, and you know the text commands us to clothe the naked, and deeds of mercy be imputed to us for faults, God help the elect.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Well, if your prodigal expenses be aimed
At any virtuous and religious end,
'Tis the more tolerable, and I am proud
You can so probably excuse yourself.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Well uncle to approve my words, as indeed good words without deeds are like your green figtree without fruit. I have sworn myself to a more conformable and strict course of life.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Well cousin, hoping you'll prove a new man.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: A new man, what else uncle, I'll be a new man from the top to toe, or I'll want of my will: instead of tennis-court, my morning exercise shall be at saint Antline's: I'll leave ordinaries, and to the end I may forswear dicing and drabbing, keep me more short uncle, only allow me good apparel, good rags I'll stand to't are better than seven years prenticeship, for they'll make a man free of any, nay of all companies without indenture, father's copy, or any help whatsoever, but I see my error, wild youth must be bridled, keep me short good uncle.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: On these presumptions I'll apparel thee,
And to confirm this resolution,
I will prefer you unto master Hobson,
A man of a well known discretion.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Any thing good uncle, I have served my prenticeship already, but bind me again and I shall be content, and 'tis but reason neither, send me to the conduit with the water-tankard, I'll beat linen, bucks, or any thing to redeem my negligence.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Your education challenge more respect.
The factor dealt for him in France, is dead.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: And you intend to send me in his room,

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I do indeed.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I 'tis well done uncle, and 'twill not be amiss in policy to do so: the only way to curb a dissolute youth as I am, is to send him from his acquaintance, and therefore send me far enough good uncle, send me into France and spare not, and if that reclaim me not, give me o'er as one passed all goodness.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Now afore God my thoughts were much against him,
And my intent was to have chid him roundly,
But his submissive recantation.
Hath made me friends with him, come follow me,
I'll do thee good, and that immediately.

sp.speaker: John:
sp.p: Thank you good uncle, you'll send me into France, all forboone: and I do not show you the right trick of a cousin afore I leave England, I'll give you leave to call me cut, and cousin me of my patrimony as you have done.
sp.stage: Enter Hobson's prentices and a boy.

sp.speaker: 1. Prent.
sp.p:
Prithee fellow goodman, set forth the ware, and
look to the shop a little, I'll but drink a cup of wine with a customer at the rose and crown in the poultry, and come again presently.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: Foot I cannot, I must needs step to the dagger in cheap to send a letter into the country unto my father, stand by, you are the youngest prentice, look you to the shop.
sp.l: Where be these varlets, bones a me, at tavern?
Knaves, villains, spend goods, foot my customers
Must either serve themselves, or pack unserved.
Now they peep like Italian pantelownes
Behind an arras, but I'll start you knaves,
I have a shooing-horn to draw on your liquor,
What say you to a piece of a salt eel?
Come forth you hangdogs, bones a me the knaves
Fleer in my face, they know me to too well,
I talk and prate, and lay't not on their jacks,
And the proud jacks care not a fig for me:
But bones a me, I'll turn another leaf.
Where have you been sir?

sp.speaker: 1. Pren.
sp.l: An honest customer
Requested me, to drink a pint of wine.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, must your crimson throat
Be scoured with wine? your master's glad of beer:
But you'll die bankrupts, knaves, and ban all.
And where have you been?

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.l: At breakfast with a dagger pie sir.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: A dagger pie! ud's daggers death, these knaves
Set cock a hope, but Hobson pays for all.
But bones a me, knaves either mend your manners.
Leave alehouses, taverns, and the tippling mates,
Your punks, and cockatrices, or I'll clap ye
Close up in bride well, bones of me I'll do't,

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.l: Beseech you sir, pardon this first offence.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: First, bones a god, why 'tis your common course,
And you must needs be gusling, go by turns,
One to the alehouse, and two keep the shop.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.l: It shall be done sir, how much ware you'd you have?

sp.speaker: Pedlar
sp.l: Five pounds worth in such commodities,
As I bespoke last night.

sp.speaker: 1. Pren.
sp.l: They are ready sorted.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: God bless you m. Hobson.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a god, knave, thou'rt welcome what's the news
At bawdy Barnewell, and at Sturbridge fair?
What, have your London wenches any trading?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: After the old sort sir, they visit the tollbooth, and the
Bullring still.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Good girls, they do their kind, what your packs empty?
Good news, a sign you bring your purses full,
And bones a god, full purses must be welcome:
Sort out their wares: welcome's your due:
Pay the old debt, and pen and ink for new.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: We have for you sir, as white as bear's teeth.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a god, knaves you are welcome, but what news?
What news i'the country? what commodities
Are most respected with your country girls?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Faith sir, our country girls are a kin to your London courtiers, every month sick of a new fashion, the horning busk and silken bride-laces are in good request with the parsons wife, your huge poking stick, and French periwig, with chambermaids, and waiting-gentlewomen, now your Puritans poker is not so huge, but somewhat longer, a long slender poking stick is the all in all with your Suffolk Puritan, your silkband, half farthingales, and changeable foreparts are common, not a wench of thirteen but wears a changeable forepart.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: An ancient wearing: there's some changeable stuff
Has been a wear with women, time out of mind.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Besides sir, many of our young married men, have ta'en an order to wear yellow garters, points, and shootyings, and us thought, yellow will grow a custom.

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.l: T'as been used long at London.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p:
And 'tis thought 'twill come in request in the country
too, 'tis a fashion, that three or four young wenches have promised me their husbands shall wear, or they'll miss of their marks: than your mask, silk-lace, wash't gloves, carnation girdles, and busk-point suitable, as common as coals from Newcastle, you shall not have a kitchenmaid scrape trenchers without her wash't gloves, a dairy-wench will not ride to market to sell her buttermilk, without her mask and her busk.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Still a good hearing, let the country pay
Well for their pride, 'tis gratis here at London,
And that's the cause 'tis grown so general.
But feed their humours, and do not spare,
Bring country-money for our London ware.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Where's m. Hobson, cry you mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No harm good m. Gresham, pray draw near:
I'll but dispatch a few old customers,
And bend a present ear to your discourse.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: At your best leisure.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Nay my task is done:
Oh m. Gresham was a golden world
When we were boys, an honest country-yeoman,
Such as our fathers were, God rest their souls
Would were white karfie: bones a me you knaves,
Stools for these gentlemen, your worships welcome.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: You know my business.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: About your kinsman,
He shall be welcome: beseech you gentlemen
Less of your courtesy: when shall we see the youth?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Why this is he.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Which, bones a me man, which?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Why this.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Which, where, what this young gentleman!
Bones a me man, he's not for Hobson's turn.
He looks more like my master then my servant.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I must confess he is a gentleman,
And my near kinsman: were he mine own child,
His service should be yours.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I thank you for't,
And for your sake I'll give him entertainment?
But gentleman if you become my man,
You must become more civil: bones a me,
What a curled pate is here? I must have't off,
You see my livery, Hobson's men are known
By their freeze coats: and you will dwell with me,
You must be plain, and leave of bravery.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I hope sir to put on such civil conformity, as you shall not repent my entertainment.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Pray God it prove so.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.l: If he do respect
An uncle's love, let him be diligent.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Well, m. Gresham, partly for your love,
And chiefly to supply my present want,
Because you say your kinsman is well seen
Both in languages and factorship,
I do intend to send him into France,
In trust both with my marchandzies and my cash.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: And if I take not order to cashier that and myself too, a pox of all french-farthingales.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: How stand you minded to your master's motion?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Somewhat unwilling to leave my acquaintance, but good uncle, I know you send me out of love, and I hope 'twill be a means to call me home the sooner.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Pray God it may.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I'll want of my will else, I'll play a merchant's part with you, I'll take up French commodities, velvet kirtles, and taffery foreparts; I'll ha' that I go for, or I'll make half the hothouses in deep smoke for this trick.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: What are your books made even with your accounts?

sp.speaker: 1 Pren.
sp.l: I have compared our wares with our receipt,
And, sinned sir, ten pounds difference.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me knave,
Ten pounds in a morning: here's the fruit
Of dagger pies, and alehouse-guslings:
Make even your reckonings, or god's mother knaves,
You shall all smart for't.
Hark you fellow goodman,
Who took the ten pound of the country chapman.
That told my master the new fashions?
Fore God not I.
Nor I.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, knaves,
I have paid soundly for my country news:
What was his name?
Now afore God, I know not.
I never saw him in the shop till now.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Now bones a me, what careless knaves keep I,
Give me the book, what habit did he were?
As I remember me, a tawny coat.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Art sure: then set him down John tawnycoat.
Ten pound in trust unto John tawnycoat.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a God man, these knaves will beggar me.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Byâ€™r lady sir, ten pounds is too much to lose,
But ten times ten pound cannot shake your credit.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Thank God for all: when I came first to town,
It would have shaken me shrewdly: but m. Gresham.
How stands your difference with sir Thomas Ramsey?
Are you made friends yet?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: He is so obstinate,
That neither juries, nor commissions,
Nor the entreaties of his nearest friends,
Can stoop him unto composition.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: 'Tis passing strange: were Hobson in your coat,
Ere I'd consume a penny amongst lawyers,
I'd give't poor people, bones a me I would.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: A good resolve: but sit Thomas Ramsey's mind
Is of another temper, and ere Gresham
Will give away a tittle of his right,
The law shall beggar me.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, man, 'twill do that quickly.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: To prevent which course,
The lady Ramsey hath by earnest suit,
Procured the reverent preacher doctor Nowell,
A man well reckoned for his grave respect.
To compromise and end our difference,
The place the Lombard, ten of clock the hour
Appointed for the hearing of our cause.
Shall I request your friendly company,

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: With all my heart, both company and purse:
Bones a me, knaves, look better to my shop:
Men of our trade must wear good husbands eyes,
Amongst many chapmen there are few that buys.
My leisure now your business attends,
Time's won not lost, that's spent to make men friends.
sp.stage: Enter doctor Nowell, and my lady Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Good master doctor Nowell, let your love
Now show itself unto me: such as they,
Men of the chiefest note within this city
To be at such a jar, doth make me blush
Whom it doth scarce concern: you are a good man,
Take you the course in hand and make them friends,
'Twill be a good days work, if so it end.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: My lady Ramsey, I have heard ere this
Of their contentions, their long suit in law,
How by good friends they have been persuaded both,
Yet both but deaf to fair persuasion:
What good will my word do with headstrong men?
Breath blown against the wind, returns again.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Although to gentlemen and citizens,
They have been so rash, yet to so grave a man,
Of whom none speak but speak with reverence,
Whose words are gathered in by every ear
As flowers receive the dew that comfort them,
They will be more attentive: pray take it in hand,
'Tis a good deed, 'twill with your virtue stand.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: To be a make-peace doth become me well,
The charitable motion good in you,
And in good sooth 'twill make me wet mine eyes,
To see them even, have been so long at odds.
And by my means, I'll do the best I can,
But God must bless my words, for man's but man.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I thank you heartily, and by the hour I know.
They will be presently here on the Lombard,
Whither I drew you for this intent:
And see, sir Thomas is come: pray break with him.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Good day to sir Thomas Ramsey.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: M. Deane of Paul's, as much to you:
'Tis strange to see you here in Lumber-street,
This place of traffic whereon merchants meet.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: 'Tis not my custom: but sir Thomas.
sp.stage: Enter m. Gresham, and old Hobson. Hob. come, come:
sp.l: Now body a me, I swear not every day,
You are too to much to blame: two citizens,
Such as yourself, and sir Thomas Ramsey are,
To beat yourselves in law six or seven year,
Make lawyers, turneys clerks, and knaves, to spend
Your money in a brabbling controversy,
Even like too fools: see where the other is,
With our Dean of Paul's, ne'er better met,
We two as umpires will conclude a strife
Before the clock strike twelve, that now is eleven:
Lawyers this full seven year have brabbled in,
And with a cup or two of merry-godown,
Make them shake hands: is't not well said m. Deane?

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: And I could wish it as well done, m. Hobson.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I'll have you both know though you are my friends,
I scorn my cause should stoop or you'll to him,
Although he be reputed Ramsey the rich.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: And Gresham shall perceive that Ramsey's purse,
Shall make him spend the wealth of Osterley,
But he shall know.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Know, what shall I know?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: That Ramsey is as good a man as Gresham.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: And Gresham is as good a man as Ramsey.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Tut, tut, tut, Gresh tut in thy teeth although thou art

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, you are both to blame: (A knight.
We two like friends, come to conclude your strife,
And you like fishwives fall a scolding here.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: How stands the difference twixt you my good friends?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The impatience both of the one and other,
Will not permit to hear each other speak:
I'll tell the cause for both, and thus it is.
There is a lordship called Osterley,
That m. Gresham hath both bought and built upon.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: And 'tis a goodly manor, m. Deane.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Which Osterley before he dealt therein,
Sir Thomas my husband here did think to buy,
And had given earnest for it.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Then Gresham here, deals with the land-seller,
And buys my bargain most dishonestly.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: God for his mercy touch mine honesty,
Away with compromise, with taking up,
The law shall try my cause and honesty.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: 'Twill prove no better than it should Gresham.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: 'Twill prove as good as Ramsey's, Ramsey.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Do not I know thy rising?

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.l: Ay, and I know thine.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Why mine was honestly.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: And so was mine.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Hey day, bones a me
Was't ever seen two men to scold before?
Here's, I know thy rising, and I know thine,
Whenas God's blessing, that hath raised them both.
Am I worse because in Edward's days,
When popery went down, I did engross
Most of the beads that were within the kingdom,
That when Queen Mary, had renewed that church,
They that would pray on beads were forced to me:
I made them stretch their purse-strings, grew rich thereby,
Beads were to me a good commodity.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: No matter for your beads, my right's my right.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Yet Gresham shall well know he hath done me wrong.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: There's law enough to right you, take your course.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Reason being made man's guide, why is't that force
Are violent passions to sweep the soul
Into such headlong mischiefs: 'tis only this,
Reason would rule, nature a rebel is.
You know the fire of your contention,
Hath only cherishing and is maintained
From vild affections, whose strength's but thâ—â—
as sultry heat doth make us shun the fire,
An extreme cold doth alter that desire:
All things that have beginnings, have their ends.
Your hate must have conclusion, then be friends.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Friends, m. doctor Nowell, look you here,
Here's m. Gresham's hand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll bring the tother.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: This seven year they have been in law together.
How much such men as they in seven years spend,
Lawyers may laugh at, but let wise men judge.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Friend Hobson.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Wife lady.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, I'll hold you fast,
I will not have a couple of such men
Make cackling lawyers rich, and themselves fools,
And for a trifling cause: as I am old Hobson.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Sir Thomas Ramsey's.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Master Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Body of me, both shall be schooled, m. D. Nowell,
You know the cause that this contention,
Is only that he bought a piece of land
This had given earnest for, all Adam's earth,
And Adam's earth is free for Adam's sons,
And 'tis a shame men should contend for it:
Whatever you speak shall for a sentence stand,
And being spoke, they shall shake hand in hand.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: If I must then decide the difference,
Thus it shall be: because that sir Thomas Ramsey's,
Had earnest given before you bought the land,
Though you were not acquainted with so much,
I do award he have a hundred pound
Towards his charges, and for that you
Have both paid for the land, and built upon it,
It shall continue yours: the money you have spent,
Either account it lost, or badly lent.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: God's precious, I have spent five hundred pound,

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: And so have I.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No matter.
The judgement stands, only this verdict too,
Had you before the law foreseen the loss,
You had not now come home by weeping cross.
Strifes may as well have end twixt honest men,
Lawyers set fools to law, then laugh at them.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Fore God 'tis true: and now I think upon it,
We might at first have ended it by friends,
And made ourselves merry with the money:
But being done, 'tis done, than sir Thomas Ramsey,
Let's leave both losers', 'tis but a thousand pound,
And if you be as well content as I,
Here we'll shake hands and let our anger die.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Shake hands, by the marie god, sir Thomas what else,

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: You show yourselves our friends, to make us friends,
Then in good sooth I'll not be obstinate.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Nay, m. doctor Nowell join their hands,
I know the reverent regard of you
Hath tempered both their hearts.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis true: I think to any but so good a man,
We should have both been headstrong: but come.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: With all my heart, long may you live together,
As friend should be to friend, brother to brother.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Amen, amen, sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Amen, amen, master Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Amen, amen, to you both.
And is not 'tis better than every term to trot after lawyers?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Good sooth 'tis true, if we could think it so,
But 'tis man's nature, he desires his woe.
Now passion of me sir Thomas, a cruel storm,
And we stay long we shall be wet to the skin,
I do not liked, nay and it angers me
That such a famous city as this is,
Wherein so many gallant merchants are,
Have not a place to meet in, but in this,
Where every shower of rain must trouble them:
I cannot tell but if I live: let's step into the Pope's head,
We shall be dropping dry if stay here:
I'll have a roof built, and such a roof,
That merchants and their wives, friend and their friends
Shall walk underneath it as now in Paul's.
What day of the month is this?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Day m. Gresham, let me see:
I took a fellow's word for twenty pound
The tenth of march, the tenth of march.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: The tenth of march, well if I live,
I'll raise a work shall make our merchants say,
Was a good shower that fell upon that day. How now Jack?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Sir, my m. here having preferred me to be his factor into
I am come to take my leave of you. (France

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I thank him for his care of thee: m. Hobson,
My kinsman's come to take his leave of me,
He tells me you are sending him for France.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me knave, art there yet?
I thought thou hadst been half way there by this.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I did but stay sir, to take my leave of my uncle.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: O m. Hobson, he comes in a very good time,
I was bethinking me whom I might send
To fetch this hundred pound, I am set to pay
To sir Thomas Ramsey: nay, as we are friends
We'll have all covenants kept before we part.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: God grant that I may see it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Here John take this sealed ring,
Bid Timothy presently send me a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I sit.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I am sure he hath it ready told for thee,
We'll stay here on the Lombard till thou comest.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Nay stay good John, thou knowest my dwelling John?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: In Paul's churchyard sir.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: The hundred pound thou art sent for, bring it thither

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Yes marry will I sir.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: And my good friends, since that so long a strife
Hath end by my persuasion, I'll entreat,
My house may entertain you for this time.
Where with such necessaries we'll pass the time,
As God shall best be pleased, and you contented:
I keep no riot, nor you look for none,
Only my table is for every one.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: A cup of sack and welcome m. Deane,
Nature is best contented with a mean.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: As I told you Timothy,
You must send my uncle straight a hundred pound:
'A dines at doctor Nowel's, and gave me in charge
To haste with the money after him.

sp.speaker: Thimo.
sp.p: You come to me John for a hundred pound, I thank my spiritual maker I have the charge of many hundreds of his now John: I hope John you fear God. (Too.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Fear God, 'sfoot what else, I fear God and the devil

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.p: I must tell you John and I know it, you have not fed of the spiritual food, but edified by faith and suffered the tares of the wild affections to be burned.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Foot thou wouldst not have me make myself a French martyr, to be burned at these years wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.p: I have known them John of our church, have been burned for other sins before thy years.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I by my faith Timothy it may be you have, for as close as you carry your teeth together, with indeed good brother, I do not think but once in a year, a man might find you quartered betwixt the mouth at Bishopsgate, and the preaching place in spittle.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Now you talk of the spittle, I must say in very deed I have been in the spittle.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: It is the more like Timothy you have been acquainted with the pox then.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: But if you should think John, that I would be there to commit, deal, or to speak more profanely, to venture in the way of all flesh, you do wrong me being a brother of the faith.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Come right yourself and your master then, and send him this one hundred pound, here's his sealed ring, I hope a warrant sufficient.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Upon so good security John, I'll fit me to deliver it.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Spend it, God send me but once to finger it, and if I do not make a Flanders reckoning on't, and that is as I have heard mad wags say, receive it hear and revel it away in another place: let me be spit out of the room of good fellowship, and never have so much favour to touch the skirt of a taffety petticoat.
sp.l: Tut I am young, mine uncle's an old chuff,
And I'll not want by God, since he hath enough.
I must not let this same wainscot-face, yea and nay, hear me though.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Here John, accept my duty to my master, I must tell you John, I would not have trusted you John, without so sufficient a discharge.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I am the less beholding unto you, but now I have't, because you preached to me upon my demand of it, I'll be so bold to lecture to you upon your delivery, Timothy you know the proverb good Timothy, that the still sow eats all the draff: and no question the most smooth tongued fellow, the more arrant knave: God forbid I should call you so Timothy, yet I will leave this for your further remembrance.

lg.l: Under the yea and nay, men often buy
Much cozenage, find many a lie:
He that with yea and nay makes all his sayings,
Yet proves a Judas in his dealings,
Shall have this written o'er his grave,
Thy life seemed pure, yet died a knave.

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.p: Do you hear John, you know the chapman's word in London, I'll trust you but no further than I see you, you have the hundred pound John, but for that you have wronged us that love to be edified, I will go with you to my master, and see the money delivered.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Why, a trusted me to come with't.

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.l: I care not by yea, and nay, I'll go by yea and nay, I will.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Let me but ask thee this question, whither dost thou go, in any love to thy master, or to me?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Though my master be my master, yet you have stirred my stomach.

sp.speaker: John:
sp.p: I thought there was the fruit of your Puritan patience, come let's along, and if I do not show your religion a trick shall be scarce digested with pepins or cheese, let me be called cut, come along.
sp.stage: Enter honesty the sergeant, and Quiek.

sp.speaker: Honesty.
sp.p: Fellow quick, pray thee have a care if thou canst see John the upholster, I must needs arrest him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: How much is the debt?

sp.speaker: Honesty.
sp.l: Some 50. li.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Dost thou think he is able to put in bail to the action?

sp.speaker: Honesty.
sp.l: I think scarce enough.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why then we'll arrest him to the Popes-head, call for the best cheer in the house, first feed upon him, and then if he will not come off, carry him to the counter, but if he will stretch some 4. or 5. li. being the sums so great he shall pass, we'll make him swear he shall not tell he was arrested, and we'll swear to the creditor we cannot meet with him.

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.l: Fore God thou sayst well.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I have served sent the perfumer, tallow the currier, quarrel the glazier, and some three or four more of our poor smelts so this morning.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Heart I have courest thorough two or three lanes, yet the miching slave follows me so close I can not give him the slip for this hundred pound: as God save me now 'tis in my hand I do rather be hanged then part from it: foot, 'twill make a man merry half a year together in France, command wenches or any thing: part from it quoth you, that were a jest indeed: shall a young man as I am, and though I say it indifferent proper, go into a strange country, and not show himself what mettle he is made of when 'a comes there: I protest a very good hundred pound, a hundred pound will go far in France, and when a man hath it not of his own, who should he make bold withal for it, if he may not with his uncle; but see if that thin faced rogue be not come again, I must have a trick for him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: For all your fore-long too and fro, by yea and nay, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Will you, there should be sergeants hereabouts , will you: lord if it be thy will send me to hit of one, and if I do not show you a trick, thou shouldst be a sergeant by thy peering so.

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.l: Why m. John so I am. (Thy name?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Thou art happily met: I am looking for one, what's

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: My name m. John, I have been merry at your uncle's many a time, my name's honesty.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I'faith.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Nay, I'll assure you his name is honesty, and I am quick

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Honesty! who the pox gave thee that name? (His yeoman.
But thou must do an office for my uncle:
Hear quick, run thou before and enter the action,
There's money, an action of an hundred pound
Against Timothy Thin-beard, m. Gresham's factor,
I hope I shall teach you to dog me.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: An action against Thin-beard, I go.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Here honesty, there's money for thy arrest,
Be sure to take good bail or clap him fast:
I hope I shall show you a trick.

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.l: Mum for that.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: See where he is, God prosper it.
Fasten upon him like a hungry dog upon a piece of meat:
And if this be not a trick to chaste a fool,
A more knave learn me, and I'll go to school.

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.l: I arrest you sir.

sp.speaker: Tim:
sp.l: Arrest me, thou servant to Sathan: at whose suit?

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.l: At your masters, m. Gresham's.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O God for thy mercy, m. John, m. John.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Nay, nay, this 100. li, hath other work in hand for me,
You are in the devil's hand, and so agree.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: My good friend, now what must become of me?

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.p: Unless, we shall to the tavern, and drink till you can send for bail, you must to the counter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Is there no difference made betwixt the faithful and the unfaithful.

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.p: Faith very little in paying of debts: but if you be so holy, I marvel how you run so far behind hand with your m.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
I must confess I owe my m. 500. li. How I came so, it is not fit to lay the sins of our flesh open to every eye, and you know
the saying, 'tis bad to do evil, but worse to boast of it: yet he above knows that sometimes as soon as I have come from bowe-church, I have gone to a bawdy-house. (Your knavery.

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.l: Nay it appears so, that now your m. hath smelled out

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Not to commit in very deed good friend, but only to see fashions or to recreate and stir up our drowsy appetites.

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.p: Well here comes my fellow quick, and unless you will content us for staying, you must along to the counter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I hope you think the labourer is worthy of his hire: we will stay here at the tavern, and quick I will content thee, to carry a letter to my master, wherein I will make him a restitution of his 500. li. by repentance, and show him the way that my frail nature hath run into.

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.l: Well, we'll be paid by the hour.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: It will not be amiss if you buy an hourglass.
sp.stage: Enter D. Nowel, Gresham. sir Tho. Ramsie, Hobson, lady Ramsie,

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Come m. D. Nowell, now we have done
Our worst to your good cheer, we'd fain be gone:
Only we stay my kinsman's long return,
To pay this hundred pound to sir Thomas Ramsey.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Then assure you, he will be hear presently:
In the mean time, I have drawn you to this walk,
A gallery, wherein I keep the pictures
Of many charitable citizens:
That having fully satisfied your bodies,
You may by them learn to refresh your souls.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Are all these pictures of good citizens?

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: They are, and I'll describe to you some of their births,
How they bestowed their lives, and did so live
The fruits of this life might a better give.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: You shall gain more in showing this to us,
Than you have shown.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Good m. Deane, I pray you show it us.
This was the picture of sir John Philpot sometimes mayor,
This man at one time, at his own charge,
Levied ten thousand soldiers, guarded the realm
From the incursions of our enemies:
And in the year a thousand three hundred and eighty,
when Thomas of Woodstock, Thomas Percy with other noble
Were sent to aid the Duke of Brittany, (Men,
This said John Filpot furnished out four ships
At his own charges and did release the armour
That the poor soldiers had for victuals pawned.
This man did live when Walworth was lord maior
That provident, valiant, and learned citizen,
That both attached, and killed the traitor Tyler,
For which good service Walworth the lord maior,
This Filpot, and four other aldermen,
Were knighted in the field.
Thus did he live, and yet before he died
Assured relief for thirteen poor for ever.

sp.speaker: Gres:
sp.l: By the marry God a worthy citizen:
On good my dear.

sp.speaker: Now:
sp.l: This sir Richard Whitington three times mayor,
Son to a knight, and prentice to a mercer,
Began the library of Gray-friars in London;
And his executors after him did build
Whittington college, thirteen almshouses for poor men,
Repaired s. Bartholomew's in Smithfield,
Glazed the Guildhall, and built Newgate.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones of me than I have heard lies,
For I have heard he was a scullion,
And raised himself by venture of a cat.

sp.speaker: Now:
sp.l: They did the more wrong to the gentleman.
This sir John Allen mercer and mayor of London,
A man so grave of life that he was made
A privy counsellor to King Henry the eight,
He gave this city a rich collar of gold,
That by the mayor succeeding should be worn;
Of which sir William Laxton was the first,
And is continued even unto this year,
A number more there are, of whose good deeds
This city flourished.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.l: And we may be ashamed,
For in their deeds we see our own disgrace,
We that are citizens are rich as they were.
Behold their charity in every street,
Churches for prayer, almshouses for the poor,
Conduits which bring us water: all which good
We do see and are relieved withal,
And yet we live like beasts, spend time and die,
Leaving no good to be remembered by.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Among the storeys of these blessed men,
So many that enrich your gallery,
There are two women's pictures: what were they?

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: They are two that have deserved a memory,
Worthy the note of our posterity:
This Agnes foster, wife to sir A. foster,
That freed a beggar at the grate of Ludgate,
Was after mayor of this most famous city,
And builded the southside of Ludgate up,
Upon which wall these verses I have read.

lg.l: Devout souls that pass this way,
For m. foster late mayor honestly pray,
And Agnes his wife to God consecrate,
That of pity this house made for Londoners in Ludgate :
So that for lodging and water here nothing they pay,
As their keepers shall answer at dreadful doom's day.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O what a charitable deed was this!
This aue Gibson who in her husband's life,
Being a grocer, and a sheriff of London,
Founded a free school at Ratcliffe,
There to instruct threescore poor children,
Built fourteen almshouses for fourteen poor
Leaving for tutors 50. li. A year,
And quarterly for every one a noble.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why should not I live so, that being dead
My name might have a register with theirs.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Why should not all of us being wealthy men,
And by God's blessing only raised; but
Cast in our minds how we might them exceed
In godly works, helping of them that need.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me 'tis true: why should we live,
To have the poor to curse us being dead?
Heaven grant that I may live, that when I die,
Although my children laugh, the poor may cry.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: If you will follow the religious path,
That these have beat before you, you shall win heaven,
Even in the midday walks you shall not walk the street.
But widows' orisons, laysars prayers, orphans thanks,
Will fly into your ears, and with a joyful blush,
Make you thank God that you have done for them:
When otherwise they'll fill you ears with curses,
Crying we feed on woe, you are our nurses.
O is't not better that young couples say,
You raised us up, than you were our decay:
And mother's tongues teach their first born to sing,
Of your good deeds, then by the bad to wring.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No more m. D. Nowell, no more,
I think these words should make a man of flint.
To mend his life: how say you m Gresham?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Fore-god they have starred tears into my eyes,
And m. D. Nowel you shall see
The words that you have spoke, have wrought effect in me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And from these women I will take a way,
To guide my life for a more blessed stay.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.l: Begin then whilst you live, least being dead,
The good you give in charge be never done,
Make your own hands your executors, your eyes overseers,
And have this saying ever in your mind:
Women be forgetful, children be unkind,
Executors be covetous, and take what they find.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: In my time I have seen many of them.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I'll learn then to prevent them whilst I live,
The good I mean to do; these hands shall give.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: The matter you wot of sit is done.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Done knave, what's done?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Is in hucksters handling sir, and hear he commend him unto you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Marry God knave dost tell me riddles, what's all this?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: A thing will speak his own mind to you,
If you please but to open the lip.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Be your leave gentlemen, I am come to smell out my master here: your kinsman John sir, your kinsman John.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: O he has brought the hundred pound, where is he?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: It appears by this, the matter is of less weight.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: What more paper:!
Fellow, what hast thou brought me here, a recantation?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: It may be so for he appears in a white sheet.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Indeed he seems sorry for his bad life ..

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Bad life, bad life knave, what means all this?
M. D. Nowell, pray read it for me,
And I'll read that my kinsman John hath sent:
Where is he knave?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Your worship is no wiser than you should be, to keep any of that coat.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Knave thou meanest.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Knave I mean sir, but your kinsman John,
That by this time's well forward on his way.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Heyday, what have we here, knavery as quick as eels?
We'll more of this.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You were best let me help you hold it sir.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Why knave, dost think I cannot hold a paper.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Help will do no hurt for if the knavery be as quick as an eel, it may chance to deceive you.

lg.l: I am a merchant made by chance,
And lacking coin to venture:
Your hundred pound's gone towards France,
Your factor in the counter.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No sir, he is yet but in the tavern at counter gate, but he shall soon be in if you please.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Away knave, let me read on.

lg.l: My father gave me a portion,
You keep away my due:
I have paid myself a part to spend,
Here's a discharge for you.

sp.l: Precious coal, here's a knave round with me.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Your factor Timothy thin beard writes to you,
Who as it seems is arrested at your suit.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: How, at my suit!

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: And hear confesseth by using bad company,
He is run behind hand five hundred pound.
And doth entreat you would be good to him.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: How, run behind hand five hundred pound,
And by bad company: m. Deane of Paul's,
He is a fellow seems so pure of life,
I durst have trusted him with all I had had.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Here is so much under his own hand.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Ha, let me see, who set you to arrest him?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Why your kinsman John sir, your kinsman John.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: He, ha, in faith I smell the knavery then:
This knave belike mistrusting of my kinsman,
Would come along to see the money given me:
Mad Jack having no trick to put him off,
Arrests him with a sergeant at my suit,
There went my hundred pound away: this Thin-beard then
Knowing himself to have played the knave with me,
And thinking I had arrested him indeed,
Confesseth all his tricks with yea, and nay:
So here's five hundred pound come, one run away.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me, m. Gresham, is my man John
Gone away with your hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Faith it appears so by the acquittance that I brought.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: No matter m. Hobson, the charge you trust him with,
I'll see he shall discharge, I know he is wild,
Yet I must tell you I'll not see him sunk:
And afore-god it hath done my heart more good,
The knave had wit to do so mad a trick,
Then if he had profited me twice so much.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: He ever had the name of mad Jack Gresham.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Is the more like his uncle, sir Thomas Ramsey
When I was young I do remember well,
I was as very a knave as he is now.
Sirrah, bring Thin-beard hither to me, and sir Thomas Ramsey,
your hundred pound I'll see you paid myself:
Ha ha, mad Jack, gramercy for this slight,
This hundred pounds makes me thy uncle right.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: I sure 'tis in this lane, I turned on the right hand coming from the stocks, nay, though there was master carls, man carels, and all careless, I'll still be honest John, and scorn to take any man's ware but I'll pay them for it: I warrant they think me an arrant knave, for going away and not paying, and in my conscience the master cudgeled the men, and the men the master, and all about me, whenas God save me I did it innocently. But sure this is the lane, there's the windmill, there's the dog's head in the pot, and here's the friar whipping the nun's arse: 'tis here about sure.
sp.stage: Enter in the shop 2. of Hobson's folks, and opening the shop.

sp.l: Come fellow crack, have you sorted up those wares?
Marked them with 54. they must be packed up.
I have don't an hour ago: have you sealed up
My master's letter to his factor John Gresham?
It is at deep in France to send him matches,
For he must use them at Bristol fair.
Ay, and the post received it two hours since.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Sure it is here about, the kennel was on my right hand, and I think in my conscience I shall never have the grace of God and good luck, if I do not pay it: God's foot, look here, look here, I know this is the shop by that same stretch-halter, oh my masters, by your leave good fellows.

sp.l: You are welcome sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Indeed that's the common saying about London, if men bring money with them.

sp.l: O sir, money customers to us are best welcome.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: You say well, so they should be. come turn o'er your books, I am come to pay this same ten pound.
And we are ready to receive money: what might we call your name?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Why my name is John Goodfellow, I hope I am not ashamed of my name.
Your kin are the more beholding to you, fellow crack turn o'er the calendar, and look for John Goodfellow.

sp.l: What comes it to?

sp.speaker: Tawnie.
sp.l: Ten pound.
You will have no more wares with you, will you sir.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Nay prithee not too fast, let's pay for the old before we talk of any new.
John Goodfellow, fellow nimble-chaps, here's no such name in all our book.
I think thou art mop-eyed this morning, give me the book, letter i, letter i, letter I: when had you your ware?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: I had it some ten days ago.

sp.p: Your name's John Goodfellow you say, letter i, letter i, letter I: you do not come to mock us, do you. Letter i, letter i, letter I. By this hand if I thought you did, I would knock you about the ears afore we parted fellow crack, get me a cudgel ready; letter i, letter i, letter I: foot here's no such name in all our book. Do you hear fellow are you drunk this morning, to make us look for moonshine in the water?

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: Fut, art not thou drunk this morning, canst not receive the money that's due to thee? I tell thee I had ten pounds worth of ware here.
And I tell thee John goodfellow, here's no such name in our book, nor no such ware delivered.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: God's precious, there's a jest indeed, so a man may be sworn out of himself, had not I ten pounds worth of ware here?

sp.l: No goodman goose, that you had not.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: Hyday, here's excellent fellows, are able to make their master's horns grow through his head in a month, they cannot only carelessly deliver away his ware, but also they will not take money for it when it comes.
Do you hear hoyden, and my master were not in the next room, I'd knock you about ears for playing the knave with us, ere you parted.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: By the mass I think your master had more need knock you about the ears, for playing the jacks with him, there's your ten pounds, tell it out with a wanion, and take it for your pains.
Fut, here's a mad slave indeed will give us ten pound in spite of our teeths.
Fellow nimble chaps, alas let the poor fellow alone, it appears he is besides himself.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: By the mass, I think you will sooner make your master stark mad, if you play thus with everybody .

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.l: Hyday, bones a me, here's lazy knaves.
Past eight o'clock , and neither ware sorted,
Not shop swept.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: Good morrow to you sir, have you any more stomach to receive money, than your men have this morning?

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.p: Money is welcome chaffer, welcome good friend, welcome good friend.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.l: Here's monsieur Malapart your man, scorns to receive it.

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.l: How knaves, think scorn to receive my money?
Bones a me grown proud, proud knaves, proud.

sp.p: I hope we know sir you do not use to bring up your servants to receive money unless it be due unto you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No bones a me knaves, not for a million:
Friend, come to pay me money, for what, for what,
For what come you to pay me money?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Why sir, for ware I had some month ago,
Being pins, points, and laces,
Poting sticks for young wives, for young wenches glasses,
Ware of all sorts which I bore at my back
To sell where I come, with what do you lack, what do you lack?
What do you lack?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Bones a me a merry knave: what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: My name sir is John Goodfellow,
An honest poor pedlar of Kent.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: And had ten pound in ware of me, a month ago:
Bones give me the books, John Goodfellow of Kent.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: O sir, nomine et naturae, by name and nature,
I am as well known for a goodfellow in Kent,
As your city summer's known for a knave,
Come sir will you be telling.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Tell me of no tellings ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ of me here's no such matters
Away knave away, thou owest me none, out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: How, owe you none say you! this is but a trick to try my honesty now.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: There's a groat, go drink a pint of sack,
Comfort thyself thou art not well in thy wits;
God forbid, pay me ten pound not due to me.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: God's dickens here's a jest indeed, master mad, men mad, and all mad, here's a mad household: do you hear m. Hobson, I do not greatly care to take your groat, and I care as little to spend it, yet you shall know I am John, honest John, and I will not be out faced of my honesty, here I had ten pounds worth of ware, and I will pay for it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Nimble-chaps, call for help nimble-chaps,
Bones of me the man begins to rave.
Master I have found out one John Tawnycoat,
Had ten pounds worth of ware a month ago.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Why that's I, that's I: I was John Tawnycoat then,
Though I am John Gray-cote now.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: John Tawnycoat! welcome John Tawnycoat.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Foot do you think I'll be out faced of my honesty?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: A stool for John Tawnycoat, sit good John Tawnycoat.
Honest John Tawnycoat, welcome John Tawnycoat.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Nay, I'll assure you we are honest all the generation of us,
There 'tis to a doit I warrant it, you need not tell it after me,
Foot do you think I'll be out faced of mine honesty?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Thou art honest John, honest John Tawnycoat:
Having so honestly paid for this,
Sort up his pack straight worth twenty pound,
I'll trust thee honest John, Hobson will trust thee:
And any time, the ware that thou dost lack,
Money or money not, I'll stuff thy pack.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: I thank you master Hobson, and this is the fruit of honesty.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Be your leave m. Hobson, I bring this favour to you,
My royal mistress Queen Elizabeth,
Hath sent to borrow a hundred pound of you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: How, bones a me, Queen know Hobson, Queen know
And send but for one hundred pound: friend come in; (Hobson?
Come in friend, shall have two, Queen shall have two:
If Queen know Hobson, once her Hobson's purse,
Must be free for her she is England's nurse:
Come in good friend, ha, Queen know Hobson,
Nay come in John we'll dine together too.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Make up my pack and I'll along from you
Singing merrily on the way,
Points, points, gloves, and purses,
Poking-sticks, and black jet-rings,
Cambrics, lawns, and pretty things:
Come maids and buy my back doth croak,
I have all that you want: what do you lack?
What do you lack?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Our city's sword-bearer and my very good friend,
What have our honourable court of aldermen
Determined yet shall Gresham have a place,
To erect this worthy building to his name,
May make the city speak of him for ever.

sp.speaker: Sword-bearer
sp.l: They are in earnest counsel sir about it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Be you my agent to and fro to them,
I know your place and will be thankful to you:
Tell them I wait here in the mayor's court,
Beneath in the sheriff's court my workmen wait
In number full a hundred, my frame is ready,
All only stay their pleasure, than out of hand
Up goes my work, a credit to the land.

sp.speaker: Sword-bearer
sp.l: I shall be dutiful in your request.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Do good m. sword-bearer, now when this work is
It shall be in the pleasure of my life, (Raised,
To come and meet our merchants at their hour,
And see them in the greatest storm that is
Walk dry, and in a work I raised for them:
Or fetch a turn within my upper walk,
Within which square I have ordered shops shall be
Of neat but necessariest trades in London.
And in the richest sort being garnished out,
'Twill do me good to see shops with fair wives
Sit to attend the profit of their husbands:
Young maids brought up young men as prentices.
Some shall prove masters and speak in Gresham's praise,
In Gresham's work we did our fortunes raise.
For I dare say both country and the court,
For wares shall be beholding to this work.
sp.stage: Enter swordbearer, lord mayor, and sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Sword-bearer
sp.l: M. Gresaam,
Thus sends the lord mayor and court of aldermen.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Or rather come to bring the news ourself:
We have determined of a place for you
In Cornhill, the delightful of this city,
Where you shall raise your frame: the city at their charge
Hath bought the houses and the ground, (Pound;
And paid for both three thousand five hundred three and twenty
Order is given the houses shall be sold,
To any man will buy them and remove them,

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: Which is already done, being fourscore households,
Were sold for 478. pound.
The plot is also plained at the city's charges,
And we in name of the whole citizens,
Do come to give you full possession
Of this our purchase, whereon to build a burse,
A place for-marchants to assemble in,
At your own charges.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: M sherife I'll do't, and what I spend therein,
I scorn to lose day, neglect is a sin:
Where be my work men?

sp.speaker: Workman
sp.l: Here, here with trowel and tools ready at hand.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Come fellows, come:
We have a frame made, and we have room
To raise it: but m. D. Nowell, and m. Hobson,
We have your presence in a happy time,
This seventh of June we the first stone will lay
Of our new burse, give us some bricks:
Here's a brick, here's a fair sovereign,
thus I begin, be it hereafter told
I laid the first stone with a piece of gold.
He that loves Gresham follow him in this,
The gold we lay, due to the workmen is.

sp.speaker: Workman
sp.l: O God bless m. Gresham, God bless m. Gresham.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: The mayor of London m. Gresham follows you:
Unto your first this second I do fit,
And lay this piece of gold a top of it.

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.l: So do the sheriffs of London after you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: And bones of me, old Hobson will be one,
Here's fellows there's my gold give me a stone.

sp.speaker: Workman
sp.l: God forbid a man of your credit should want stones

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Is this the plot sir of your work in hand?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: The whole plot both of form and fashion.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: In sooth it will be a good edifice,
Much art appears in it: in all my time
I have not seen a work of this neat form:
What is this vaultage for, is fashioned here?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Stowage for merchant's ware and strangers goods,
As either by exchange or otherways are vendable.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Here is a middle round and a far space,
The round is greater, and the space
Seems open: your conceit for that?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: The grates give light unto the cellarage,
Upon the which I'll have my friends to walk,
When heaven gives comfortable rain unto the earth:
For that I will have covered,

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: So it appears.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: This space that hides not heaven from us,
Shall be so still, my reason is,
There's summer's heat, as well as winter's cold,
And I allow and here's my reason for't,
'Tis better to be bleaked by winter's breath,
Than to be stifled up with summer's heat:
In cold weather walk dry and thick together,
And every honest man warm one another:
In summer then when too much heat offends,
Take air a god's name merchants or my friends.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: And what of this part that is over head?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: M. Deane in this:
There is more ware there then in all the rest,
Here like a parish for good citizens
And their fair wives to dwell in, I'll have shops
Where every day they shall become themselves
In neat attire, that when our courtiers
Shall come in trains to pace old Gresham's burse,
They shall have such a girdle of chaste eyes,
And such a globe of beauty round about:
Ladies shall blush to turn their vizards off,
And courtiers swear they lied when they did scoff.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Kind m. Gresham this same work of yours,
Will be a tomb for you after your death,
A benefit to tradesmen and a place
Where matchants meet their traffic to maintain,
Where neithÃ¨r could shall hurt them, heat, nor rain.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: O m Nowell I did not forget
The troublesome storm we had in Lumbar-fleet,
That time sir Thomas and I were adversaries,
And you and m. Hobson made us friends.
I then did say, and now I'll keep my word,
I saw a want and I would help afford:
Nor is my promise given you when you showed
That rank of charitable men to us,
That I would follow their good actions
Forgotten with me, but that before I die,
The world shall see I'll leave like memory.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Fore-god my lord, have you beheld the like!
Look how it streaks, what do you think of it?

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.l: 'Tis a strange comet m. Hobson,
My time to my remembrance hath not seen
A sight so wonderful. M. D. Nowell,
To judge of these things your experience
Exceedeth ours, what do you hold of it?
For I have heard that meteors in the air,
Of lesser form, less wonderful than these,
Rather foretell of danger's imminent,
Then flatter us wish future happiness.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.l: Art may discourse of these things none can judge
Directly of the will of heaven in this,
And by discourse thus far I hold of it.
That this strange star appearing in the North,
And in the constellation of Cassiopey,
Which with three fixed stars commixed to it,
Doth make a figure geometrical,
Lozengewise called of the learned Rombus,
Conducted with the hourly moon of heaven,
And never altered from the fixed sphere,
Foretells such alteration that my friends,
Heaven grant with this first sight our sorrow ends.

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.l: God, will be done m. Deane, hap what hap will,
Death doth not fear the good man but the ill.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Well said m Hobson.
Let's have a day, that if death come tomorrow
He's rather messenger of joy then sorrow.
Now sir what news from Barbary?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Unwelcome news sir, the King of Barbary is slain.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Ha, slain by treason or by war.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: By war, in that renowned battle,
Swift fame desires to carry through the world:
The battle of Alcasar, wherein two Kings
Besides this King of Barbary was slain,
Kings of Morocco and of Portugal,
With Stewkeley that renowned Englishman
That had a spirit equal with a King,
Mad fellow with these Kings in warlike strife,
Honoured his country and concluded life.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Could news byâ€™r lady, the venture gentlemen
Of threescore thousand pound with that dead King,
Lies in a hazard to be won or lost:
In what estate consists the kingdom now?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: In peace, and the succeeding happy,
Was crowned then King when I took ship from thence.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: To that King then be messenger from us,
And by the sound of trumpet summon him?
Say that thy master and a London merchant,
craves due performance of such covenants
Confirmed by the late King unto ourself,
That for the sum of threescore thousand pound,
The traffic of his sugars should be mine.
If he refuse the former bargain made,
Then freely claim our money that we lent:
Say that our coin did stead the former King,
If he be kind we have as much for him.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: By the mary-god it was a dangerous day,
Three Kings beside young Stewkeley slain:
I'll tell you my lord mayor what I have seen
When sword and bucklers were in question,
I have seen that Stewkeley beat a street before him,
He was so familiar grown in every mouth,
That if it happened any fighting were,
The question straight was, was not Stewkely there.
Bones a me he would hew it. Now, what news with you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here is a letter sent you from John Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: O an answer of a letter that I sent,
To send me matches against Bristol fair,
If then any were come.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I cannot tell sir well what to call it, but instead of matches of ware, when you read your letter, I believe you will find your factor hath matched you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: What's here, what's here.
sp.p: As near as I could guess at your meaning, I have laboured to furnish you, and have sent you 2. thousand pounds worth of match.
How, bones knave, 2. thousand pounds worth of match!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Faith m. never chafe at it, for if you cannot put it away for match, it may be the hangman will by some of it for halters.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Bones a me, I sent for matches of ware, fellows of ware.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And match being a kind of ware, I think your factor hath matched you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: The blazing star did not appear for nothing:
I sent to be sorted with matches of ware,
and he hath sent me naught, but a commodity of match,
And in a time when there's no vent for it.
What do you think on't gentlemen,
I little thought Jack would have served me so.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Nay m. Hebson grieve not at Jack's cross,
My doubt is more and that I laugh at less.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: You have travelled sir, how do you like this building?
Trust me it is the goodliest thing that I have seen,
England affords none such.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Nor Christendom:
I might say all the world has not his fellow.
I have been in Turkey's great Constantinople,
The merchants there meet in a goodly temple,
But have no common burse in Rom, but Rome's
Built after the manner of Frankford, and Eniden:
There where the greatest marts and meeting places
Of merchants are have streets and penthouses,
And as I might compare them to themselves,
Like Lumberstreet before this buisse was built.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: I have seen the like in Bristol.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Good morrow to your honours.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Thanks to my good lord major.
We are gazing here of m. Gresham's work.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: I think you have not seen a goodlier frame.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Not in my life, yet I have been in Venice,
In the Rialto there called s. Marks,
'Tis but a babble if compared to this.
The nearest that which most resembles this,
Is the great burse in Antwerp, yet not comparable
Either in height or wideness: the fair cellarage,
Or goodly shops above: oh my lord major,
This Gresham hath much graced your city London,
His fame will long outlive him.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: It is reported you sir Thomas Ramsey are as rich as he.
This should incite you to such noble works,
To eternize you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Your lordship pleases to be pleasant with me,
I am the meanest of a many men
In this fair city, m Gresham's fame
Draws me as a spectator amongst others,
To see his cost, but not compare with it,

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: And it is cost indeed.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: But when to fit these empty rooms about here,
The pictures graven of all the English Kings
Shall be set over and in order placest,
How glorious will it then be?

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: These very pictures will surmount my wealth.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: But how will m. Gresham name this place?

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: I heard my l. of Leicester to the Queen
Highly commend this work, and she then promised
To come in person and here christen it,
It cannot have a better godmother:
This Gresham is a royal citizen.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: He feasts this day the Russian ambassador,
I am a bidden guest:
Where if it please you.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: Good sir Thomas,
We know what you would say, we are his guests
Invited two: yet in our way we took
This wonder worth our pains, it is our way
To Bishopsgate to m. Gresham's house,
Thither so please you we'll associate you.
sp.stage: Enter Gresham leading in the ambassador, music, and a banquet served in: the ambassador set: enter sir Tho. Ramsie, the 2. Lords, my lady Ramsie the weights in sergeants gowns with one interpreter.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Lords all at once welcome, welcome at once,
You come to my new buildings up sitting,
It hath been long in labour now deliver.
Anon we'll have a health to it.
This Russian prince the emperor's ambassador
Doth not our language understand: interpreter,
Say that the we bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Interpreter
sp.l: The prince speaks Latin,
And in that language we'll interpret for him:
Salutem tibi optat et adicentum tuum gravissume iste londinensis.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: Istum libens audio, ages illi meo nomine ex animo gratias, funde quod bibamus.

sp.speaker: Interpreter
sp.l: He gladly thanks you for his royal welcome
And drinks to you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: We understand that sign.
Come let our full crowned cups o'erflow with wine,
Welcome again fair lords.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Thanks m. Gresham.
We have been viewing of your works.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: My burse how do you like it lord,
It is a pretty babble.

sp.speaker: 2. Lo.
sp.l: 'Tis a fair work.
Her majesty intends to name the place.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: She doth her servant Gresham too much grace,
It will be pretty when my pictures come
To fill those empty rooms, if that holds,
That ships rich is worth her weight in gold.

sp.speaker: 1. Lo.
sp.l: It will be rare and famous.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: What was it that the Russian whispered?

sp.speaker: Interpreter
sp.l: He ask me what interpreter the Queen
Would in his embassy employ.

sp.speaker: Giesh.
sp.l: None, tell him none.
For though a woman, she is a rare linguist,
Where other princes use interpreters,
She propria voce, I have some Latin too:
She of herself hears all their embassies,
And herself answers them without interpreter,
Both Spanish, Latin, French, and Greek,
Dutch, and Italian, so let him know:
My lord of Leicester sent me word last night,
And I am prouder on't then on my building,
the Queen to grace me and my works the more,
The several ambassadors then will hear,
And them in person answer.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis most true.
sp.stage: Enter a gentleman whispering to sir Thomas Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Gresham.
sp.l: The Russian with the frence.
What would that gentleman sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: He is a merchant and a jeweller:
Amongst other stones he saith he hath a pearl
Orient and round, weighing so many carets
That it can scarce be valued: the French King,
And many other Dukes have for the riches
And prize refused to buy it: now he comes,
To offer it to this ambassador.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Show him the pearl interpreter:
The lord ambassador.

sp.speaker: Interpreter
sp.l: Mercator quidem et aurifex spectandum, tibi profere
Gemmam dominae serenissime.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: Et pulchra et principe digna, interroga quanti iudicat?

sp.speaker: Interpreter
sp.l: He commends it to be both rich and fair,
And desires to know how you value it.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: My prize sir, is fifteen hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: Quantivalet?

sp.speaker: Interpreter
sp.l: Mille quin gentis minis,

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: Non, non nimis peceara est ista gemma.

sp.speaker: Interpreter
sp.l: He saith it is too dear, he will not buy it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I will peruse your pearl, is that your prize?

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: I cannot bate one crown and gain by it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: We'll not be accessary to your loss,
And yet consider all things some may think us
To be but bare of treasure at this time,
Having disbursed so much about our works:
Yet if our ships and trade in Barbary
Hold currant we are well: what news from sea,
How stands my ships?

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Your ships in which all the Kings pictures were,
From Brute unto our Queen Elizabeth:
drawn in white marble, by a storm at sea
Is wracked and lost.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: The loss, I weigh not this:
Only it grieves me that my famous building,
Shall want so rich and fair an ornament.

sp.speaker: L. Ram.
sp.l: It touches all the city; for those pictures
Had doubly graced this royal edifice.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Methinks the ship's loss most should trouble you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: My ships but wealth, why we have wealth;
The pictures were the grace of my new burse,
So I might them in their true form behold,
I cared not to have lost their weights in gold.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: A noble citizen.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Our factor, what good news from Barbary?
What says the King, speak, didst thou summon him?
Or hast thou brought my threescore thousand pound?
Or shall I have the sugars at that rate?
If so, new marble pictures we'll have wrought,
And in a new ship from beyond-sea brought.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: The King that in the regal chair succeeds
The King late dead I summoned, and demanded
Either your money tendered, or the sugars
After the rate proposed, he denied both
Alleging though he was successive heir,
He was not therefore either tide to pay
The late King's debts, nor yet to stand unto
Unnecessary bargains: notwithstanding
To gratify your love, the King hath sent you
As presents, not as satisfaction:
A costly dagger, and a pair of slippers,
And there's all for you threescore thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Byâ€™r lady a dear bargain.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: I fear me this will plague him, a strange cross,
How will he take this news, loss upon loss.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p: Nay, will it not undo him, doth he not wish his buildings in his purse.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: A dagger that's well,
A pair of slippers come unto my shoes,
what 30. thousand pound in sterling money,
And paid me all in slips, than hoboys play,
On slippers I'll dance all my care away:
Fit, fit, he had the just length of my foot.
You may report lords when you come to court,
You Gresham saw a pair of slippers wear
Cost thirty thousand pound.

sp.speaker: 1, Lo.
sp.l: Somewhat too dear.
Nor yet for all this treasure we have lost,
Repents it us one penny of our cost.

sp.speaker: 2. Lo.
sp.l: As royal in his virtues as his buildings.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: These losses would have killed me.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: Jeweller,
Let's see thy pearl: go pound it in a mortar,
Beat it to powder then return it me,
What Dukes, and lords, and these ambassadors
Have even before our face refused to purchase
As of too high a price to venture on,
Gresham a London merchant here will buy.
What is it broken small? fill us some wine,
Fuller, yet fuller till the brim o'erflows,
Here 16000. pound at one clap goes,
In stead of sugar, Gresham drinks this pearl
Unto his Queen and mistress: pledge it lords,
Whoever saw a merchant bravelier fraught,
In dearer slippers or a richer draught?

sp.speaker: L. Ram.
sp.l: You are an honour to all English merchants
As bountiful as rich, as charitable
As rich as renowned as any of all.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.l: I do not this as prodigal of my wealth,
Rather to show how I esteem that loss
Which cannot be regained, a London merchant
Thus tread on a King's present: jeweller,
My factor shall deliver you your money.
And lords so please you but to see my school,
Of the seven learned liberal sciences,
Which I have founded here near Bishopsgate,
I will conduct you. I will make it lords
an university within itself,
And give't from my revenues maintenance.
We're not like those that are not liberal
Till they be dying, what we mean to give,
We will bestow, and see done whilst we live.
Attendance, come, th'ambassador, guess all,
Your welcome's great, albeit your cheer's but small

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.l: Hard world, when men dig living out of stones,
As wretched miserable I am enforced:
And yet there lives more pity in the earth,
Then in the flint-bosoms of her children,
For she's content to have her aged breast
Mangled with mattocks, rent and torn with spades,
To give her children and their children bread,
When man more flinty than her stony ribs
That was their mother, neither by entreats,
Tears, nor complaints will yield them sustenance,
But 'tis our age's fault the mightier,
Tear living out of us, we out of her.
sp.stage: Enter Hobson in his gown and slippers.

sp.speaker: Hob.
